data.title: Conflict: a Distributed Condition: Contemporary War Ecologies
data.desc:
Conflict is not an exception or an isolated event — it is a constant condition running through society. It is not limited to war or explicit clashes: it emerges within collective life as friction, as a continuous confrontation between competing needs, systems, and visions.
It is not a punctual episode but a latent and distributed condition. It takes on asymmetric, often invisible forms, embedded in cultural practices, social relations, and infrastructures. Its logic is not confined to violence: it also structures coexistence, shaping who holds privilege and who is pushed to the margins.
Exploring distributed conflicts means reading the present as a field where techniques of offense multiply and blur into the infrastructures society depends on. The goal is to generate critical devices, scenarios, and questions that probe the ambiguous nature of conflict as a diffuse condition in a post-territorial age.

data.title: Primissime idee
data.desc:
Very initial ideas following the delivery of the brief:
Ecologism taken to the extreme, engineering of nature, speciesism. Following the review, in which we were asked to start from a much broader research rather than immediately diving into possible scenarios.

Issues: the meaning of conflict and the meaning of ecology.

data.title: Definizioni
data.desc: General research on definitions of the theme. Individual deep dives into the topic of ecological conflict revealed that some themes overlapped, leading us to identify four macro-themes of ecological conflict. It is important to always ask: where is the conflict? Is the theme we are reflecting on truly ecological, or are we veering into other types of conflict (e.g., value-based)?

data.title: Artificiale = iperecologico
data.desc: The artificial as hyper-ecological, within a non-anthropocentric vision that places all living beings on the same level.

data.title: Conflitto genera conflitto
data.desc:
Human conflict as a generator of ecological conflicts.

We fear that this theme might be too predictable.

data.title: Conflitto tiene l'equilibrio
data.desc:
Ecosystem imbalance as a consequence of a total absence of conflict.
Alternatively: there is no ecology without conflict.

data.title: Parallelismo
data.desc: Parallelism between current conflicts and “natural” conflicts (e.g., predator-prey dynamics) to reflect on conflict as something feral and animalistic, yet natural.

data.title: Ulteriore ricerca
data.desc: Following the previous review, in which we were asked to be more specific about the themes and to focus on ecological issues that concern humans, we have outlined three themes.

data.title: Paradosso
data.desc:
Theme of the paradox.
• What if the artificial were considered more sustainable than the natural?
• What if the direction of biomimicry completely replaced nature?

data.title: artificiale / naturale
data.desc:
• If everything becomes manipulated or uncontrollable, what truly remains “natural”?
• How much of our “humanity” do we lose when we increasingly rely on technologies that, by imitating what was once natural, manage to control us?

data.title: Temporalità incompatibili
data.desc:
• What if time were a finite resource to be redistributed?
• And what if we had to negotiate our rhythms with those of ecosystems? What form would a society synchronized with the rhythms of the Earth take?

data.title: Review
data.desc:
The project has improved compared to the previous version.

Suggestions:
• Consider various anthropocentric perspectives (egocentrism, biocentrism, cultural centrism).
• Nature appears too passive: the narrative should instead subvert the established order, offering a different and more conflictual point of view.
• It is important to use the term “human being” instead of “man.”
• The conflict should not be limited to “human vs. nature,” but should also include “human vs. human,” showing more specific and segmented dynamics.

It is emphasized that ecological conflict is not necessarily violent, but rather brutal and devoid of empathy: nature is not “green” or harmonious, but a complex and competitive system.

data.title: Scenario 2 – Plant's sound
data.desc: Plants have evolved to communicate their stress through piercing cries. Walking on the lawn, drought, cutting the flowerbed, deforesting, weeding — all create agonizing screams. Instead of finding a way to prevent plants from suffering, humanity invents a device that allows you not to hear the pain.

data.desc: AAAAAAA DA SCRIVERE

data.title: Research post-review
data.desc:
Greater research and more in-depth analysis are needed of situations in which nature does not merely endure the effects of human activity, but acts actively and interacts with the environment.

Ecosystems, species, and natural phenomena continuously respond to changes imposed by humans, altering biological cycles, local climates, and social dynamics. Studying these active interactions allows for a better understanding of ecological conflict.

data.title: Ecocentrism
data.desc: Ecocentrism is a worldview that places nature at the center, attributing intrinsic value to it and not just viewing it as a resource for humans. It opposes anthropocentrism, which sees humans as the focal point of everything, and promotes an approach based on respect, ecosystem conservation, and the pursuit of a harmonious balance between humanity and the environment.

data.title: Deforestation theme
data.desc: Deforestation represents the act by which humans take space and resources from the natural ecosystem, compromising the benefits they themselves receive. In a speculative scenario, this logic is reversed: humans become the object of exploitation or must restore the lost ecosystem services, paying the price for their own actions.

data.title: Water memory theme
data.desc: Humans use water primarily as a resource to exploit, but water is not actually a passive entity, as it can perceive information from the external environment, analyze it, and retain it in its “memory.”

data.title: Agroterrorism theme
data.desc: Agroterrorism: a form of subversive struggle targeting the agri-food sector through malicious or criminal acts. Agroterrorism can use pests or biological agents to damage production, the economy, and food security, threatening consumer trust and national well-being.

data.title: Sound theme
data.desc: Plants under stress — due to cutting, dehydration, or other conditions — emit ultrasounds similar to clicks or crackles, inaudible to humans but detectable with special microphones. A team from Tel Aviv University, in collaboration with Harvard, has shown that these “cries” propagate through the air, revealing a form of plant communication that has been little studied until now.

data.title: Scenario Hypothesis - Certification / Labeling Brand
data.desc:
Fictitious Name: EticaAlimentare – European Transparent Certification System
What it does:
Offers a new label guaranteeing “absence of contamination from bio-engineered organisms.”
Born in response to the collapse of local crops.
Becomes a tool both for cultural defense (“protection of traditions”) and aggressive marketing.

Why it is interesting:
It reaches the consumer during shopping.
Appears ethical and neutral, but is loaded with ideology, politics, and social pressure.
Divides the market: those with the label and those without.
Raises tension in the conflict without producing anything, simply by regulating the narrative around food.

data.title: Review
data.desc:
• It was discussed how to present the projects: start from the premises, then move to the core issue, and finally the “what if.”


Scenario 1
Paradox: works well but needs clearer communication, introducing the theme of standardization and clarifying the group’s role (a company producing artificial trees with a platform for “lymphatic credits”). The advisor asks, “And then?”, to encourage further narrative development.


Scenario 2 
Struggle Against Oneself: interesting but too complex; it should be simplified and made more plausible. The idea of a machine that measures pain could help highlight the ecological conflict.


Scenario 3
Agroterrorism: too many themes and overdeveloped “what ifs.” The concept of plants as weapons works but should be made more concrete, perhaps from the perspective of a seed-weapon manufacturer.

data.title: Presentation and Review
data.desc:
Morning → Presentation
Afternoon → Review (prof. Guida) + reading comments on presentation


Review:

Scenario 1 is promising but needs to be deepened and made more concrete, with a clear narrative that translates the three identified considerations, avoiding solutions that are too simple or literal.

For Scenario 2, Guida highlighted the need to better develop the conflict, making it narratively more engaging without falling into ideological positions. This scenario has more design challenges.

We will continue with Scenario 1.

data.title: Scenario 1 continuation
data.desc:
Scenario Redefinition:
artificial trees, initially designed to produce energy and improve air quality, become symbols of consumption and social status. Their purchase is tied to “lymphatic credit,” accumulated by cutting down natural trees, thus turning sustainability into a competitive market and incentivizing the destruction of natural ecosystems.


Identification of considerations:

1
Empathy with the conflict: the issue of ecosystem destruction, often perceived as distant, becomes a direct experience, highlighting individual human responsibility.

2
The tree as a living ecosystem: the tree is not just a plant organism but a habitat that supports many species; its removal has cascading effects on the environment.

3
Commodification and standardization: the tree becomes a consumer good with economic value and market cycles, losing its natural dimension and becoming an object comparable to any industrial product.

data.title: New research for new scenario
data.desc:
In-depth research on:

•Terminator Seeds: a type of genetically modified seed designed to produce sterile seeds, preventing their germination and thus use by farmers for subsequent crops.

•Seed Saving: the practice of collecting, preserving, and replanting seeds from existing plants to maintain crops, preserve biodiversity, and promote self-sufficiency and savings. It involves selecting healthy plants, harvesting mature seeds, drying them, and storing them in a cool, dark, and dry place.

data.title: New scenario (2)
data.desc:
Scenario:
the seed trade has become a lawless territory, completely deregulated, accessible, and free. There are natural, hybrid, and synthetic seeds: some promise exceptional yields, others eliminate pesticides, but there are also mutated seeds that do not germinate or spread diseases, and even seeds designed to kill. Anyone can legally purchase them, online or at physical distributors, freely choosing: nourishment, tool, or weapon?


Considerations:

1
Conflict Generators: nature, domesticated and reassembled, becomes a means of conflict, transformed into an arsenal that appears harmless but has disastrous consequences.
	
2
Human Intervention: by regulating nature, humans assume the power to decide what can or cannot exist, what is good and what is evil.

3
Not Naturally Good: “natural” is no longer a guarantee of authenticity: modified seeds challenge trust in nature as a safe refuge.
